Fig. 1 Time evolutions of growth Bio-AuNPs by biological synthesis from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841): (a) UV–Vis spectra of taken-out aliquots at different reaction times, showing the characteristics LSPR band around 534 nm increasing with the colloidal Bio-AuNPs formation; (b) Freshly taken out aliquots in cuvettes immediately before UV–Vis analysis; After 48 h of reaction, the stirring was stopped, and the system was cooled to room temperature. It was then kept at rest for an additional 24 h, monitoring the aggregation and sedimentation processes of the Bio-AuNPs, as shown in the digital photograph in (c). Fig. 2 Structural and morphological accomplish of Bio-AuNPs growth from bacterial culture broth; (a) XRD pattern of Bio-AuNPs (in red) recorded after 24 h of reaction and gold standard pattern from JCPDS 4-784 (in black); (b–f) TEM images of aliquots taken out at 7, 9. 12. 24 and 48 h after reaction started, respectively; (g) Schematic coalescence growth process representation; (h–i) TEM images of the sample after 72 h, 48 h shaking and 24 in rest, and (j) particle size histogram (D T E M ) of the sample after 72 h. The black bars in the insets correspond to 20 nm. Fig. 3 Time-dependence colloidal study: (a) above the hydrodynamic size (Z-average) investigated in up to 57 days and below the corresponding values to the polydispersity index (PdI); (b) Zeta potential and electrophoretic mobility measured at room temperature. The mean of 5 measurements is plotted for each data, and the error bar represents the standard deviation from these five measurements. The dashed line in the hydrodynamic size data (Z-average in (a)) is just a guide to the eye. Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have found widespread applications across chemistry, physics, biology, and medicine. Microorganisms can be used for the biological synthesis of nanoparticles under controlled conditions. In this study, the endophytic bacterium Priestia megaterium (CBMAI 2841), isolated from Lavandin inflorescences and cultured in a liquid Nutrient Broth medium, was employed for the extracellular biological synthesis of metallic AuNPs (Bio-AuNPs) without the use of toxic solvents. Highlighting the experimental novelty, the utilization of a bacterium sourced from a specific plant origin distinguishes this work from studies employing microorganisms from broader environmental niches or established laboratory strains. The bacterial biomass was separated by centrifugation, and the resulting growth supernatant (20 mL) was reacted with a 1 mmol L−1 aqueous solution of tetrachloroauric(III) acid trihydrate ( ). The bioreduction process was conducted at 32 °C and 130 rpm for 72 h. The formation of Bio-AuNPs was observed as early as 3 h of reaction, a finding confirmed by UV–Vis spectroscopy. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed that the biosynthesized Bio-AuNPs were formed through self-assembly and coalescence of smaller primary nanoparticles, resulting in an average final size of 45 nm. The aqueous suspension of Bio-AuNPs exhibited good colloidal stability, characterized by a zeta potential of approximately −18 mV and a hydrodynamic size of around 70 nm. The Bio-AuNPs were successfully applied as catalysts (0.4 mg solid Bio-AuNPs, 50 °C, 30 min, 5 mL ethanol) in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction using malononitrile and a series of aromatic aldehydes (benzaldehyde, 4-bromobenzaldehyde, 4-ethylbenzaldehyde, 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, 4-fluorobenzaldehyde, 3-nitrobenzaldehyde, 4-nitrobenzaldehyde, 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde, 3-pyridinecarboxaldehyde, furan-2-carbaldehyde, and 2-thiophenecarboxaldehyde). Notably, high yields (70%–99%) of the Knoevenagel adducts were achieved with a low catalyst mass loading within a short reaction time, using a common solvent (ethanol) at a mild temperature, suggesting enhanced catalytic efficiency compared to some reported Bio-AuNP catalysts. The bacterium P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) demonstrated efficiency in the extracellular biological synthesis of AuNPs. The rapid synthesis combined with promising catalytic activity underscores the potential of this specific bio-inspired approach. Graphical abstract MSC 00-01 99-00 Keywords Biological synthesis Gold nanoparticles Priestia megaterium bacterium Catalyst Knoevenagel reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Several methods for synthesizing gold nanomaterials have been developed over the past decades, aiming at technological applications in many areas, such as catalysis, diagnostics, therapeutics, sensors, and biosensors. Although numerous routes for the synthesis of gold nanoparticles have been described in the literature, efforts have been made to optimize new routes that adhere to the principles of Green Chemistry. These new routes allow the synthesis of materials with desirable properties for various applications while promoting environmentally friendly processes, which are increasingly important for sustainability. Examples of green chemistry routes include biological methodologies using fungi, bacteria, plants, and algae [1–5]. The green biological synthesis of metallic nanoparticles has become more attractive due to its eco-friendly, cost-effective, accessible, scalable, clean, and safe nature. These methods do not require higher temperature or pressure, nor do they involve additional reducing or stabilizing agents, thus avoiding the use of hazardous substances. Biological methodologies, including plant extracts, fungi, algae, and bacteria, can be used to synthesize metallic nanoparticles via intra- or extracellular routes. Plant extracts contain various bioactive compounds, including phytochemicals, enzymes, and cofactors, which can reduce gold ions to metallic gold, allowing nanoparticle formation. Additionally, these compounds can interact with the surface of nanoparticles to stabilize them in suspension. Similarly, microorganisms, including bacteria, fungi, and yeast, contain enzymes, secondary metabolites, and cofactors that can also reduce gold ions from a precursor solution, forming metallic nanoparticles and providing their colloidal stability [6–10]. In the literature, studies have used bacterial cells and bacterial culture broth for the biological synthesis of AuNPs. Methodologies using bacterial synthesis can be divided into intracellular and extracellular protocols. In intracellular routes, bacteria generally grow in a nutrient broth. Following growth, the biomass is separated from the broth and added to an Au + 3 solution to initiate the reaction. Nanoparticle synthesis occurs in the presence of bacterial cells. After the reaction, the gold nanoparticles are separated from the cellular medium suspension and purified by filtration or centrifugation [11–20]. Chen et al. described the synthesis of AuNPs via an intracellular route using wet biomass from Escherichia coli and Bifidobacterium lactis, yielding AuNPs with average sizes of 4.2 nm and 5.6 nm, respectively. For E. coli, a nutrient broth was used under aerobic conditions, while for B. lactis, MRS broth with 0.05% cysteine was used under anaerobic conditions. The bacterial biomass (2 g) was centrifuged and moistened in 100 mL of aqueous solution of 1 mmol L−1 HAuCl4. After the reaction, the culture solution was centrifuged, pellets were collected and resuspended in 50 mmol L−1 Tris buffer (pH 7). Then, the solution was sonicated, filtered, and the AuNPs were lyophilized at −80 °C under vacuum. The resulting AuNPs were utilized in biological assays to evaluate their antimicrobial, antioxidant, photocatalytic, and antityrosinase activities [21]. In extracellular routes, usually after bacteria growth, the biomass is separated by centrifugation, and the supernatant (bacterial culture broth) is mixed with Au 3 + solution to obtain gold nanoparticles. Camas et al. reported the synthesis of AuNPs using cells-free from Citricoccus sp. K1D109. The marine bacterium was inoculated in ISP2 medium broth. After the reaction, the bacterial solution was centrifuged, the pellets were discarded, and the supernatant was mixed with 1/5 volume of a 1 × 10−3 mol L−1 solution and incubated in a dark room at 30 °C, resulting in the formation of AuNPs with sizes ranging from 25 to 65 nm [20]. Several other examples involving the green biosynthesis of metallic nanoparticles have been published in the literature, including extensive reviews covering different systems such as plants, fungi, and bacteria [22–24]. Metallic nanoparticles can be used as catalysts in many inorganic and organic synthesis. For example, the catalytic Knoevenagel reaction is widely used in organic synthesis because it allows the formation of carbon–carbon double bonds and the introduction of other functional groups. The products of this reaction are α , β -unsaturated carbonyl compounds, which are of interest in the synthesis of molecules for application in natural products, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemistry. This reaction involves the condensation of an aldehyde or ketone with an active methylene compound, typically an ester or malonate, in the presence of a base as a homogeneous catalyst. Heterogeneous catalysts, such as zeolites, mesoporous silica, and metal oxide to graphitic carbon nitride, have also been used to improve the Knoevenagel reaction [25]. In this study, Bio-AuNPs were biologically synthesized using the endophytic bacterium Priestia megaterium (CBMAI 2841) isolated from Lavandin inflorescence, a natural hybrid of Lavanda angustifolia and L. latifolia. The bacterium Priestia megaterium, previously classified as Bacillus megaterium, is gram-positive and has wide biotechnological applications ranging from the production of vitamin B12 to the production of polymers such as polyhydroxybutyrate. Priestia sp. can also promote plant growth and is used as a biofertilizer, phytohormone, and biopesticide [26,27]. In addition, the Bio-AuNPs synthesized in our study were applied as a heterogeneous catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction. The synthesis process of these Bio-AuNPs and their colloidal stability over time were also investigated. The novelty of this work lies in two main points. Firstly, few studies in the literature report the use of endophytic bacterium Priestia megaterium in the biosynthesis of metal nanoparticles. In addition to being sustainable, the methodology presented advantages such as high colloidal stability and better gold nanoparticle size, shape, and polydispersity control. Secondly, the originality of this study is highlighted by the application of the biosynthesized green Bio-AuNPs as metal catalysts in synthesizing Knoevenagel adducts with significant yields. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first investigation involving the application of this type of metal nanoparticles in the Knoevenagel reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Benzaldehyde 1a (99%), 4-bromobenzaldehyde 1b (98%), 4-methylbenzaldehyde 1c (97%), 4-chlorobenzaldehyde 1d (97%), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde 1e, 3-nitrobenzaldehyde 1f (99%), 4-nitrobenzaldehyde 1g (99%), 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde 1h (98%), 3-pyridinecarboxaldehyde 1i (98%), furan-2-carbaldehyde 1j (98%), 2-thiophenecarboxaldehyde 1k (98%), malononitrile (99%), and tetra chloroauric acid ( ) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used without further purification. Ethyl acetate (Merck), hexane (Synth), and ethanol (Synth). The thin layer chromatography (TLC) used was DC-Fertigfolien ALUGRAM XTra SIL G/UV254 (layer: 0.20 mm silica gel 60 with fluorescent indicator UV254). 2.2 Isolation of P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) The bacterium identified as Priestia megaterium (CBMAI 2841) is Gram-positive and was isolated from Lavandin inflorescences in a 2% Malt culture medium. The Lavandin plant was collected in September 2020 at the “O Lavandário” farm, localized in the Cunha-SP/Brazil. The owner, Mrs. Maria Fernanda Freire Luis, provided a specimen of the entire plant. P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841), which was identified and deposited in the Coleção Brasileira de Microrganismos de Ambiente e Indústria – CBMAI (https://cbmai.cpqba.unicamp.br/). 2.3 Growth of P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) in solid culture medium In a beaker flask, 1 L-distilled water, 13 g-Nutrient Broth, and 20 g-Agar were added, and the solution was mixed using magnetic stirring. The pH was adjusted to 7.0 with an aqueous solution of HCl (1.0 mol L−1), and the culture medium was sterilized in an autoclave (121 °C, 1.5 kPa). After that, it was cooled to 45 °C and transferred to Petri dishes (100 mm x 15 mm). P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) was cultivated in a Petri dish containing Nutrient Broth (1.3%) and Agar (2%) (24 h, 32 °C). All manipulation was performed in a laminar flow cabinet (Veco) previously cleaned with 70% ethanol, 2% sodium hypochlorite, and UV germicidal light (254 nm) at 20 min. 2.4 Growth of P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) in liquid culture medium After the bacteria growing in a solid culture medium (24 h), using a nickel-chromium inoculation loop sterilized in a Bunsen flame, 106 CFU mL−1 (OD = 0.1) of P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) was prepared in the saline solution (0.86%). The 106 CFU mL−1 was defined by the absorbance at the wavelength of 610 nm by UV–Vis spectrophotometer (UV-1800 – Shimadzu). Then, 1 mL of the bacterial solution, in a concentration of 106 CFU mL−1, was transferred to an Erlenmeyer flask containing 50 mL of liquid culture medium and incubated in an orbital shaker (Novatecnica) for 24 h, at 130 rpm and 32 °C. All materials and glassware used were sterilized in an autoclave (Phoenix) (121 °C, 1.5 kPa, 20 min), and manipulation was performed in a laminar flow cabinet (Veco). 2.5 Biological synthesis of Bio-AuNPs from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) The biological synthesis of AuNPs was adapted from He et al. [12]. The solution containing bacterial culture broth and biomass was first transferred to a 250 mL Falcon tube. The pellets (bacterial biomass) were separated from the bacterial culture broth by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 5 min at 15 °C (Hitachi - Model CR22GIII). Then, the pellets were discarded, and 20 mL of the bacterial culture broth was transferred to another 125 mL Erlenmeyer flask and used to synthesize AuNPs. Tetra chloroauric acid ( , 1 mmol L−1) was added to the bacterial culture broth, and the mixture pH was adjusted to 7.0 with an aqueous HCl solution (1.0 mol L−1). The pH value = 7.0 was chosen to standardize an initial pH for the investigated samples since the morphological aspect of the biosynthesized nanoparticles is strongly influenced by the pH of the medium [22–24]. Additionally, the ideal pH for bacterial growth in the culture medium is 7.0, which was maintained to allow possible comparison between the two methodologies, intra- and extracellular. The flask was kept under stirring in a refrigerated orbital shaker at 130 rpm, at 32 °C, for a maximum time of 72 h. Digital photographs and UV–Vis spectroscopy analysis monitored the evolution of the reaction over time. All manipulation was performed in a laminar flow cabinet (Veco) previously cleaned with 70% ethanol, 2% sodium hypochlorite, and UV germicidal light (254 nm) for 20 min. After the reaction period, the synthesized Bio-AuNPs were analyzed by UV–Vis spectroscopy. In this case, 1 mL of the sample was added to a plastic cuvette (12.55 × 12.65 × 44.55 mm, ± 0.1 mm, with a 10 mm optical path) and analyzed. The UV–Vis absorption spectra were collected at a wavelength range from 300 to 1000 nm. The synthesis and growth of Bio-AuNPs were continuously monitored after the first two hours up to 12 h. After the initial 12 h, aliquots were recorded at 24, 48 and 72 h. The solid Bio-AuNPs, used as a catalyst in the Knoevenagel reaction, were separated from the culture broth. This involved a series of three purification cycles, with each cycle consisting of centrifugation followed by washing with pure water. After these purification steps, the nanoparticles were vacuum-dried and stored as a powdered solid. 2.6 GC–MS and NMR (1H and 13C) analyses GC–MS: The gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analyses were performed on a Shimadzu GC2010 Plus coupled to a mass selective detector (Shimadzu MS2010 Plus) in electron ionization (EI, 70 eV) mode. The analyses were performed with a DB5 column (30 m ×0.25mm × 0 . 25 μ m , J & W Scientific). The initial oven temperature was 90 °C for 4 min, then increased to 280 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, where it was held for 5 min. Finally, the temperature was increased to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 and held for 10 min, for a total analysis time of 40 min. The injector and interface temperatures were maintained at 250 °C and 270 °C, respectively. Helium was used as the carrier gas with an initial flow of 0.75 mL min−1, and the injection volume was 1 μ L (split ratio of 1:20). Fragment ions were detected in the 40–550 Da range. Porto et al. recently published the synthesis of the identical adducts shown in this work using aromatic aldehyde derivatives (malononitrile) by the Knoevenagel reaction, employing microwave irradiation as a heat source under free-catalyst conditions [28]. The synthesized adducts in the present work, where Bio-AuNPs were used as a catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction, were compared with the previous results reported in the literature [28]. The results of the GC–MS analyses for all adducts are presented in the Supporting Information (SI, Figures S1-S22). 1H and 13C NMR: The Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on an Agilent Technologies 500/54 Premium Shielded or Agilent Technologies 400/54 Premium Shielded spectrometer, with CDCl3 as solvent and tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. The chemical shifts ( δ ) were expressed in parts per million (ppm) and coupling constants (J) values were reported in Hz. Signals were referenced to the tetramethylsilane internal standard (TMS) and the deuterated solvent used CDCl3 ( δ H : 7.26 ppm, δ C : 77.1 ppm). For the 1H NMR spectra, the number of scans was 120, and for 13C NMR was 881 scans. The authors showed the detailed characterization of the Knoevenagel adducts by using 1H and 13C NMR analyses in Figures S42-S63 presented in the SI material. 2.7 Knoevenagel reaction using the Bio-AuNPs obtained from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) A mixture of aldehydes 1a-1k (0.5 mmol), malononitrile (0.5 mmol, 33.03 mg), ethyl alcohol (5 mL), and solid AuNPs (0.4 mg) was placed in a 10 mL penicillin bottle. The mixture was stirred on a magnetic plate at 280 rpm at 50 °C. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC using a mixture of hexane and ethyl acetate (8:2). Upon completion, the reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 x 10 mL). The combined organic phases were concentrated under a vacuum until the solvent was entirely evaporated. The products 3a-k were purified by washing with warm hexane, identified, characterized by GC–MS and NMR analyses, and compared with previously results reported in the literature [28]. Control reactions were conducted in the absence of the Bio-AuNPs catalyst for 3-nitrobenzaldehyde 1f, 4-nitrobenzaldehyde 1g, 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde 1h, and 2-thiophenecarboxaldehyde 1k under the same reaction conditions described in the presence of Bio-AuNPs. The adducts 3a-k were characterized by GC–MS and NMR analyses (see SI Figures S1-S22 and Figures S42-S63). 2.8 Reuse of Bio-AuNPs The durability and stability of the Bio-AuNP catalyst were evaluated through reuse in multiple cycles. In a penicillin vial, 70.3 mg (0.5 mmol) of 4-chlorobenzaldehyde 1d, 33.03 mg (0.5 mmol) of malononitrile 2, 5 mL of ethanol, and 1.4 mg of Bio-AuNPs were mixed and then stirred magnetically at 280 rpm at 50 °C for 15 min. The reaction product was subsequently analyzed by GC–MS. Finally, the material was transferred to an Eppendorf tube (2 mL), where the Bio-AuNPs were separated by washing with ethyl acetate and centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 3 min. This process was successively repeated until the Eppendorf tube maintained a constant mass. The Bio-AuNPs catalyst was reused for five consecutive cycles in the Knoevenagel reaction, using p-chlorobenzaldehyde and malononitrile, demonstrating its reusability. 2.9 Characterization of Bio-AuNPs The Bio-AuNPs were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in a diffractometer Bruker D8 Advance (with Cu K α radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å) to determine the crystallographic phase of the material. Concentrated Bio-AuNPs suspension was deposited onto a zero-background silicon sample holder, and the solvent evaporated before analysis. The XRD patterns were acquired at 0.020°in 2 θ and 0.2 s per step. Average crystallite sizes (D h k l ) corresponding to the [111] reflection (D111 ) were estimated using the Scherrer equation ( λ = 1.5418 Å and K S = 0.9). A pseudo-Voight function was fitted to extract the hkl reflection parameters used in the Scherrer equation. Particle size, shape, and size distributions of the nanoparticles were determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The analyses were conducted in a JEOL-JEM2100 LaB6 microscope operating at 200 kV. A diluted Bio-AuNPs dispersion was droplet onto a copper grid coated with sputtered carbon over a thin Formvar film. The sample was kept for 24 h under a vacuum before measurements. The size distributions and the average particle size (D T E M ) were determined by measuring at least 200 nanoparticles using the free software ImageJ 1.54i. The polydispersity degree ( σ ) was determined according to the expression σ = S D / D T E M using the standard deviation (SD) and D T E M values obtained from the lognormal fit on the nanoparticle distribution data. Time-dependence colloidal stability was accomplished during 57 days by dynamic light scattering (DLS) and electrophoretic (zeta potential) measurements. The hydrodynamic size and the surface potential (zeta potential) were examined to evaluate the aggregation state of the colloidal suspension of Bio-AuNPs. The measurements were performed at room temperature in a Zetasizer Nano ZS from Malvern Instruments. Preliminary assays showed that pH values below 8 and the support-electrolyte addition resulted in fast nanoparticle aggregation. Thus, all samples were measured in the solution’s original pH, without additional adjustments, just accomplishment of pH values before measurements, around 9. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was used to evaluate the adsorbed chemical molecules present onto the nanoparticle surface. The FTIR spectrum was recorded in the Shimadzu IRPrestige-21 equipment, ranging from 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1, and 32 scans. The samples were prepared by a mixture with freshly dried KBr (2% w/w), followed by compression to obtain a pellet. 2.10 Determination of total proteins in culture broth from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) The concentration of total proteins was determined by the modified Lowry method, using albumin as a standard at concentrations of 25 μ g mL−1, 50 μ g mL−1, 100 μ g mL−1, 150 μ g mL−1, 200 μ g mL−1, and 250 μ g mL−1. Ultrapure water (18.2 m Ω cm) at room temperature was used as a control. Absorbance reading was performed using a spectrophotometer UV–Vis (660 nm) [29]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Biological synthesis of AuNPs from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) It is important to note that the initial data (not shown) of intracellular synthesis showed nanoparticles with varied sizes and shapes, including triangular structures and nanoplates, as described by He et al. who observed similar results at pH < 7.0 using the bacterium Rhodopseudomonas capsulata [12]. Due to these inconsistencies, further studies on intracellular synthesis were discontinued and are not presented in this work. The initial selection of synthesis parameters, including a temperature of 32 °C and a stirring rate of 130 rpm, was based on the optimized conditions for the growth of the endophytic bacterium Priestia megaterium (CBMAI 2841) in Nutrient Broth culture medium. The primary objective was to optimize the cultivation of the bacteria to standardize the production of biomolecules responsible for the bioreduction of gold ions in the extracellular biosynthesis process. Additionally, the approach started with the choice of conditions considered mild for the synthesis. The initial pH of the medium was maintained at a neutral value (7.0) to minimize the stress on the biological system. However, it is important to note that continuous pH monitoring revealed a progressive alkalization of the reaction medium, reaching a value of 9.0 during the synthesis process of the metallic nanoparticles. This pH shift may have influenced the activity of the reducing biomolecules and the kinetics of Bio-AuNP formation. The low stirring rate (130 rpm) was employed to ensure homogeneity in the dispersion of the gold precursor ions within the culture medium without generating turbulent shear forces that could compromise the integrity of the secreted biomolecules or the nucleation and growth of the nanoparticles. The reaction time was initially determined based on UV–Vis spectroscopy measurements, which indicated the initial formation of nanoparticles within 3 h. However, the reaction time was extended to longer periods (72 h, as mentioned in the methodology) to monitor the evolution of nanoparticle growth, their colloidal stability over time, and potential morphological changes. This approach allowed for the acquisition of information regarding the process kinetics and the identification of a point where the formation and stability of the Bio-AuNPs were considered satisfactory. Despite the initial conditions being considered mild and optimal for bacterial growth, the observation of pH increase during nanoparticle synthesis suggests that the metabolites released by the bacterium may play an active role in modifying the reaction microenvironment, directly influencing the bioreduction process and the stability of the formed Bio-AuNPs. The initial solution containing the bacterial culture broth and gold salt appeared light yellow, slowly turning red. It is well-known that spherical AuNPs in a colloidal dispersion present a red color due to localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR). The observed color change indicates the reduction of to Au0, with the reduced Au0 acting as monomers in nucleation and growth into AuNPs. Different mechanisms have been proposed for AuNP nucleation and growth processes, but they all infer that the reduction from to Au0 occurs independently of the reactants used in the synthesis [30–33]. UV–Vis spectroscopy was used to investigate the time evolution of Bio-AuNP formation by analyzing aliquots at different reaction times (1–48 h), as shown in Fig. 1. UV–Vis spectra of these aliquots (Fig. 1(a)) show an absorption band with a maximum centered at 534 nm. No absorption band was observed for the pure culture broth of P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) in the absence of gold salt precursor solution, . The band at 534 nm is attributed to the LSPR absorption of spherical AuNPs. The LSPR band for noble metal nanoparticles can occur at different wavelengths depending on factors like the nature and composition of the metal or alloys, as well as the size, shape, and agglomeration state of the nanoparticles [34,35]. For spherical gold nanoparticles, the LSPR absorbance band typically appears between 500 and 600 nm. The AuNPs smaller than 80 nm generally present the maximum LSPR band around 520–550 nm [36]. An increase in nanoparticle size or aggregation results in a red shift of the absorption band to longer wavelengths in the UV–Vis spectrum [37,38]. The absorption band with a maximum centered at 534 nm suggests that the Bio-AuNPs formed in this study were approximately 40–50 nm in size [39]. The time evolution of the reaction showed that the Bio-AuNPs began to form after approximately 7 h. At this point, a broadened and low-intensity LSPR band was observed in the UV–Vis spectrum (Fig. 1(a)). Subsequently, the intensity of the LSPR band increased, while its full width at half-maximum (FWHM) systematically decreased as the reaction progressed, with the maximum absorption wavelength remaining around 530 nm. The increase in absorbance intensity is associated with an increase in the number of nanoparticles in suspension, hence increasing the AuNPs concentration. Nanoparticle growth appears limited to a fixed size, and no aggregation process was noted during this period, as indicated by the stable LSPR band position. This observation is also corroborated by the LSPR bandwidth, which remained relatively unchanged over time. Fig. 1(b) displays digital photographs of the Bio-AuNPs dispersions, in which aliquots were taken out of the reaction medium at different times. The aliquots exhibited increasingly intense red colors as time progressed, visually reflected in the increase in the LSPR absorption band intensity observed in the UV–Vis spectra. Although the UV–Vis analyses presented in Fig. 1(a) cover the reaction interval of up to 48 h, the reaction medium was kept at rest for another 24 h (72 h after the reaction began). Aliquots were collected at different times during these additional 24 h of rest. The digital photographs in Fig. 1(c) show eleven aliquots during this additional reaction period. The color intensity of aliquots increased with time, indicating that the reaction continued and increased the concentration of Bio-AuNPs in the reaction medium. As the reaction was conducted using the culture broth without a purification process, the formation of Bio-AuNPs continued due to the presence of enzymes, cofactors, and metabolites excreted by the bacteria still present in the solution. However, it is important to note that after 8 h of rest, the intensity of the red color began to diminish as the increased concentration of the Bio-AuNPs led to flocculation and precipitation. Fig. 2 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern and TEM images of aliquots from the Bio-AuNPs suspensions collected at different reaction times. Fig. 2(a) presents the XRD results of the aliquot taken out after 24 h, showing the characteristic peaks of gold metal in a face-centered cubic (fcc) phase, in agreement with the standard gold diffraction pattern (JCPDS 4-784). Using the Scherrer equation, the average crystallite size (D111 ) was estimated from the reflections corresponding to the (111), yielding a value of 12.5 nm. Figs. 2(b)–(f) show TEM images of aliquots collected at 7, 9, 12, 24, and 48 h, respectively. The images recorded at different reaction times indicate that small particles grew through a coalescence process. This ongoing process resulted in the formation of small organized aggregates of particles over time. Finally, these aggregates showed signs of nanocrystal coalescence and resulted in AuNPs with an average size ( D T E M ± S D ), standard deviation) of 45.1 ± 5.5 nm (Fig. 2(j)) and a degree of polydispersity ( σ = S D / D T E M ) of 12%. Figs. 2(b) and (c), taken at 7 and 9 h of reaction, respectively, show metallic gold clusters with dimensions estimated around 1 nm, as highlighted in Fig. 2(c) inset. We propose an initial approach to nanoparticle formation based on our results, which corresponds well to recent studies [32,40]. In these studies, the authors indicate that the formation of gold nanoparticles does not wholly agree with the classical nucleation and growth theory by LaMer [41–43]. The data indicate that nucleation and growth are primarily driven by coalescence processes, as suggested in our work. In our model, metal clusters measuring 1–2 nm appeared to form by the aggregation of monomers (Au0 species) reduced in the bacterial culture broth and gave rise to primary particles measuring around 4–5 nm (Figs. 2(b) and (c)). These primary particles arose from the coalescence of metal clusters and the simultaneous incorporation of new monomers. As the reaction continued, the primary particles exhibited high surface energy due to the absence of surface stabilizers (such as citrates). Consequently, these primary particles moved closer to minimize this energy, forming self-organized aggregates that underwent further coalescence, resulting in a final size of around 45 nm (Figs. 2(d)–(f)). By the end of the reaction, the larger particles tended to stabilize, with a rough surface due to the coalescence of small particles in a polycrystalline system (Figs. 2(h) and (i)). This polycrystallinity agrees with the values of the average crystallite size D111 = 12.5 nm calculated using the Scherrer equation, indicating that the final particles were, on average, formed from four crystalline domains with different orientations. Furthermore, intermediate-sized particles tended to coalesce on the surface of larger particles, as seen in Figs. 2(e) and (f). It is important to note that growth driven by coalescence processes aligns well with the UV–Vis spectroscopy data, where the LSPR band remains narrow and while only increases in intensity over time. This behavior suggests that the nucleation and growth processes do not occur simultaneously, which would result in band broadening due to the varying particle sizes in suspension. Coalescence reduces the number of primary particles, creating larger particles with similar sizes, as shown in Figs. 2(h) and (i) for the sample after 72 h (48 h shaking and 24 h at rest) and as inferred by the D T E M size histogram (Fig. 2(j)). Fig. 2(g) illustrates the proposed coalescence growth process. Thirumurugan et al. used the culture supernatant from Bacillus subtilis to synthesize AuNPs from HAuCl4 acid [44]. The reactions were conducted in a test tube kept on a shaker-type stirrer at room temperature, containing 9 mL of tetra chloroauric(III) acid and 1 mL of culture supernatant (B. subtilis). UV–Vis analysis showed an absorption band at 530 nm after 24 h, which shifted to 540 nm after 120 h [44]. In our studies using P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841), the pH during AuNPs formation was monitored over time. The reaction started at pH 7.0, increasing to pH 9.0, and which remained stable at this value after 3 h of reaction. The time-dependence of pH values in the bacterial culture broth during the extracellular Bio-AuNP biosynthesis is shown in Figure S23. Notably, the pH value of the medium for intracellular synthesis decreased from 7.0 to 6.0 and then to 5.0, suggesting that the different morphologies observed for the intracellular system may be due to the decrease in the pH of the reaction medium [12]. After 3 h, the nucleation of AuNPs is expected due to the reduction from Au 3 + to Au + or Au0, although it may not be detectable visually or through UV–Vis analysis. The reduction from Au 3 + to metallic gold is generally assigned to an electron shuttling mechanism, for example, by the cofactor NADH, forming NAD + [13]. Literature studies have shown that the cofactor NADH and NADH-dependent enzymes are essential in the biological synthesis of nanoparticles. For instance, Das et al. studied the biological synthesis of AuNPs using the extract of the fungus Rhizopus oryzae [45]. The authors observed that the reduction of Au 3 + ions occurred through the action of NADH, the cofactor associated with the enzyme responsible for the reaction. These enzymes include, for example, glutathione reductase, phytochelatin, oxidases, reductases, peroxidases, and laccases [45,46]. Our study did not investigate in depth the reduction mechanism of Au 3 + ions by the culture broth from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841). It is known that enzymes are proteins that function as biological catalysts for chemical reactions. Protein quantification revealed that the bacterial enzymatic broth contained 490 . 2 μ g mL−1 of proteins, indicating the excretion of extracellular enzymes. However, no additional identification was performed to determine the type of enzyme in the broth. Studies to elucidate the mechanism of Bio-AuNP formation are ongoing. Preliminary results from UV–Vis spectroscopy (data not shown) did not reveal the presence of NADH (or NADPH) in the bacterial culture broth. NADH species are generally reported to be responsible for reducing metal ions in the presence of reductase enzymes in a mechanism called NADH-dependent reductase [23]. Conversely, GC–MS data (Figure S24 and Table S1) suggests that fatty acid derivatives, specifically hexadecanoic (palmitic) and 9-octadecenoic (oleic) acids, along with benzoic acid, were the predominant metabolites in the bacterial culture broth. Although other components are observed in the chromatogram of Figure S24, Table S1 highlights only the components present in a more significant proportion and with a similarity index (SI) ≥ 90%. The reduction of Au 3 + ions to Au0 by carboxylic acids, or more specifically, carboxylate ions, has been reported in the literature for synthesizing gold nanoparticles. Shiraishi et al. synthesized gold nanoparticles with benzoic acid catalyzed by UV irradiation ( λ = 250 nm) [47]. Recently, Yue et al. described the synthesis of gold nanoparticles using fatty acids in a slightly heated aqueous solution (37 °C) [48]. In both studies, the authors inferred that the coordination of the carboxylate ion to the [Au 3 + Cl 4 − ] species occurred, producing the [carboxylate-Au 3 + Cl 3 − ] complex. Yue et al. also showed that the reaction proceeded through successive hydrolysis reactions and degradation of the fatty acid carbon chain, reducing the metal ions and forming branched nanoparticles of similar size (50 nm) to those observed in this work. The formation of primary nanoparticles smaller than 5 nm was associated with acid molecules generating branched nanoparticles, which agrees with the approach of the formation mechanism approach proposed here. The three identified acid species, benzoic, palmitic, and oleic acids, exhibited pKa values of 4.17, 4.75, and 5.02, respectively. In the extracellular synthesis of Bio-AuNPs, the initial pH of the bacterial broth was adjusted to 7.0, which is sufficient to maintain the acid species in a deprotonated form, favoring the formation of carboxylate ions. As the reaction progresses, the possible byproducts from the degradation of the organic species appear to contribute to the pH increase to 9.0 (Figure S23). Further studies are underway to elucidate this proposed mechanism of Bio-AuNP formation. Fig. 3 and Figure S25 show the time-dependence colloidal stability of the Bio-AuNP suspensions. The hydrodynamic sizes (Z-average) were generally larger than the TEM size, as the hydrodynamic size obtained by DLS measurements accounts for both the particles (AuNPs solute) and an additional solvation layer (water molecules). The polydispersity index (PdI) values obtained from the DLS analyses for different samples were between 0.2 and 0.32, indicating reliable hydrodynamic size results and suggesting that all samples exhibit monomodal size distributions with moderate polydispersity [49,50]. The time evolution of hydrodynamic sizes, as shown in Fig. 3(a), indicates a decrease over time, with Z-average values (hydrodynamic size) decreasing from 83.4 nm after one day to 62.3 nm after 57 days. This trend is coherent with the coalescence growth approach shown in TEM images (Fig. 2) and Figure S25, which presents TEM images taken after 57 days. In the initial days, the particles consisted of a larger core, surrounded by smaller particles aggregated, leading to larger DLS measurements. However, as time progressed, the coalescence of small particles onto the surface of the large cores led to the formation of one polycrystalline particle entity that tended to decrease the hydrodynamic sizes. Figure S26 shows histograms of the hydrodynamic sizes obtained by DLS corresponding to the values summarized in Fig. 3(a). It is important to note that all size analyses obtained by DLS (Figure S26) present a monomodal distribution. These characteristics, associated with moderate PdI values, suggest that aqueous suspensions of Bio-AuNPs present significant colloidal stability, as shown in the digital images in Fig. 1(b)–(c). Time-dependence of zeta potential and electrophoretic mobility are presented in Fig. 3(b). Zeta potential and electrophoretic mobility values showed slight variations, in which zeta potential fluctuated between −15.5 mV and −18.9 mV, while electrophoretic mobility varied between −1.212 and - 1 . 479 μ m cm V−1 s−1. Generally, it is established that in a stable suspension, the zeta potential must be below −30 mV or above +30 mV. A more detailed classification subdivides colloidal stability criteria into four zeta potential ranges: fast aggregation (between ± 5 mV), short-term stability (from ± 5 mV to ± 20 mV), good stability ( > +30 mV and < −30 mV), and excellent or long-term stability ( > +60 mV and < −60 mV) [51,52]. As previously mentioned, the hydrodynamic size distribution results observed by DLS (Figure S26) suggest that the Bio-AuNP system had good colloidal stability. FTIR data (Figure S27) suggest that the nanoparticles are stabilized by molecules containing carboxylate groups, as indicated by the deconvoluted bands in the regions of 1648 cm−1 and 1595 cm−1 attributed to asymmetric ( ν a s ( ) and symmetric ( ν a ( ) stretching vibrations of carboxylate ions, respectively. The difference in wavenumber between the asymmetric and symmetric bands ( Δ ν = 53 cm−1) infers a bidentate chelating coordination mode of the stabilizing molecules on the gold nanoparticle surface. However, it was not possible to isolate or identify the specific molecules bound to the surface. The presence of molecules with carboxylic acid groups stabilizing the Bio-AuNPs can also be correlated with the zeta potential values (Fig. 3(b)). The negative surface potential values (around −16 mV) at alkaline pH suggest the presence of deprotonated carboxylate ions. Furthermore, a previous study demonstrated that at pH values below 8, the particles rapidly flocculated, inferring the protonation of the carboxylic acid groups and the consequent loss of charge that stabilizes the nanoparticles. The suspensions remained stable throughout the time necessary to perform the analyses in quintuplicates (five consecutive scans). However, as shown in the digital images (Fig. 1(c)), when the sample was removed from the shaker and kept at rest, it was possible to observe the beginning of particle sedimentation after approximately 10 h at rest. The visual effect is noted by the continuous lightening of the initially very red suspension, which turned slightly pink after 24 h. This effect is explained by the measured zeta potential values, which indicate short-term colloidal stability, lasting only a few hours. It is worth noting that particle sedimentation does not imply an aggregation process but rather flocculation. The system quickly reverted to a very red suspension with manual shaking, and the suspension remained stable for several hours, confirming the short-term stability state. 3.2 Knoevenagel reaction using Bio-AuNPs as catalysts Initially, we reviewed the literature on Knoevenagel condensation involving benzaldehyde derivatives and malononitrile using Bio-AuNPs as heterogeneous catalysts. In several studies, the AuNP catalyst was supported in different solid frameworks such as UiO-66 (NH2-UiO-66), imidazolium-functionalized cationic covalent triazine, and amino-functionalized Al-based MIL-53 [53–55]. The combination of metal nanoparticles with porous framework support materials is reported to have an excellent catalytic performance. However, these catalyst supports often require high amounts of catalyst, toxic solvents, and elevated temperatures. Therefore, we investigated the development of an easier catalyst preparation route using the biological synthesis of AuNPs from P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) bacteria for direct application to Knoevenagel condensation, avoiding the need for toxic solvents. 3.3 Knoevenagel reaction optimization with biological AuNPs The Knoevenagel adduct 3c was selected to optimize the reaction process. Reaction times were evaluated at 15 min, resulting in yields of 5% and 21% of adduct 3c, without and with Bio-AuNPs, respectively (Table 1, entry 1). Figure S28 shows these data in a graphic format. In all cases, the yield was determined by GC–MS. When the reaction was conducted in the presence of Bio-AuNPs, the yield improved from 70% to 93% for adduct 3c over reaction times ranging from 60 to 300 min (Table 1, entries 2–7). Notably, at 60 min, the yield of adduct 3c without Bio-AuNPs was 75%, while the presence of AuNPs yielded 90% of adduct 3c. The second parameter studied was the catalyst mass of Bio-AuNPs. Initially, the reaction used 0.2 mg of solid Bio-AuNPs to achieve a 43% yield of adduct 3c (Table 2, entry 1). The yield of adduct 3c improved to 70% with the use of 0.4 mg-AuNPs (Table 2, entry 2). When the catalyst mass of Bio-AuNPs was doubled to 0.8 mg, a 92% yield of adduct 3c (Table 2, entry 3) was observed. In addition, 1.6 to 4.0 mg of solid Bio-AuNPs yielded 98%–99% yields of adduct 3c (Table 2, entries 4–7). For this study, entry 2 was selected as the optimal condition, as it achieved a yield of 70% of adduct 3c using a catalyst mass 4 times lower than entry 3, under the same reaction conditions (Table 2). The last parameter evaluated was the temperature using a fixed catalyst mass of 0.4 mg of solid Bio-AuNPs. Initially, the Knoevenagel reaction was carried out at room temperature (25 °C) to give a 36% yield of adduct 3c (Table 3, entry 1). When the temperature was increased to 40 °C, a slight increase in the yield of adduct 3c Table 3, entry 2) was noted. At 50 °C, a 70% yield of adduct 3c was obtained (Table 3, entry 3). Notably, reactions conducted at temperatures above 50 °C provided yields for adduct 3c (Table 3, entries 3–5) similar to those obtained at 50 °C. Finally, the scope of the Knoevenagel reaction was obtained using the optimized conditions (50 °C, 30 min, 5 mL ethanol, 0.4 mg Bio-AuNPs) in the presence of aromatic aldehydes 1a-k and malononitrile 2 (Table 4). The synthesis of adducts 3a-k was successful for all cases, achieving 77% to 99% yields. All compounds were identified by GC–MS (Figures S1-S22, SI), 1H and 13C NMR analyses (Figures S42-S63, SI), and compared with similar compounds previously synthesized in our laboratory and reported in the literature [28]. The use of Bio-AuNPs showed that this new material is an efficient catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction, achieving good yields (up to 90%), compared to literature, that generally requires special conditions such as microwave reactors, alkaline catalysts, and other conditions [28,53–55]. Lolak et al. reported the Knoevenagel condensation reaction using Pd-Ni nanoparticles supported on graphene oxide as a catalyst. Under specific conditions (1 mmol of benzaldehyde, 1.1 mmol of malononitrile, 10 mL of ethanol, and 2 mg of catalyst), a yield of 65% was achieved after 100 min at room temperature [56]. In contrast, our study, employing Bio-AuNPs as the catalyst with the same substrates, yielded 91% of the Knoevenagel adduct in a significantly shorter reaction time of 30 min. Şen et al. investigated rhodium/platinum nanoparticles supported on thiocarbamide-functionalized graphene oxide for the Knoevenagel condensation. In an optimized reaction (1.0 mmol of 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, 0.5 mmol of malononitrile, 2.0 mg of catalyst, and 1.5 mL of ethanol at room temperature for 120 min), a yield of 15% was obtained [57]. Comparatively, our AuNPs catalyst facilitated the same reaction with a yield of 99% of the Knoevenagel adduct within 30 min. Kumar et al. evaluated the catalytic activity of nickel nanoparticles (Ni-NPs with 15–20 nm) in the Knoevenagel reaction. Using 5 mmol of 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, 6 mmol of malononitrile, and 10 mol% Ni-NPs in ethanol at 25 °C, a yield of 97% was observed after 15 minutes [58]. In our study, using Bio-AuNPs with comparable reagents yielded 99% of the Knoevenagel adduct after 30 min. Thus, the Bio-AuNPs show promise as a new catalyst for aldol-type organic chemistry reactions. 3.4 Reuse of the Bio-AuNPs For the reuse experiment, 1.4 mg of Bio-AuNPs as a catalyst was initially added in the Knoevenagel condensation using p-chlorobenzaldehyde 1d and malononitrile 2 in ethanol (5 mL) for 15 min at 50 °C. Under these conditions, 99% reaction conversion was achieved for the first cycle (Table 5, cycle 1). After implementing the catalyst recovery methodology, no loss in the mass of the Bio-AuNP catalyst (1.4 mg) was observed. Thus, the second cycle was conducted under the same conditions using the recovered catalyst mass of 1.4 mg, resulting in an identical conversion of 99% (Table 5, cycle 2). In the third cycle, the reaction was performed using the Bio-AuNPs remaining after the recovery methodology. In this case, slight catalyst mass loss was observed after washing and centrifuging, recovering 1.3 mg (0.1 mg loss). Although the catalyst mass used in the third cycle was nearly the same as in the first two cycles, the third cycle showed a 65% reaction conversion, with 35% of the p-chlorobenzaldehyde remaining unconverted (Table 5, cycle 3). The fourth and fifth cycles were conducted under the same conditions using the remaining catalyst mass after the respective recovery methodology. As observed after the third cycle, there was a decrease in reaction conversion (4th cycle – 62% and 5th - cycle 42%). This phenomenon can be explained by the moderate loss of Bio-AuNP catalyst mass during the recovery procedure (4 cycles – 0.9 mg and 5 cycles – 0.8 mg). GC–MS analyses for the fourth and fifth cycles indicate that 38% and 49% of the aldehyde were not converted, respectively. These results affirm that the loss of catalyst mass decreased the conversion reaction. Additionally, the reduced conversion values may also be associated with substrate adsorption on the catalyst surface, which can reduce the number of free active sites on the catalytic material. The data suggest that catalyst poisoning (blocking active sites) becomes more pronounced from the third cycle onwards. 4 Conclusions The enzyme broth from bacteria P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) was successfully utilized to biosynthesize metallic gold nanoparticles from a solution containing Au 3 + ions. After 3 h of reaction, primary metallic gold particles (Bio-AuNPs) measuring around 2 nm were nucleated. These nuclei underwent a process of self-organization followed by coalescence, resulting in stable polycrystalline aggregates with an average size of 45 nm, as determined by TEM images. The Bio-AuNPs showed good colloidal stability with zeta potential and hydrodynamic size (Z-average) close to −18 mV and 70 nm, respectively. The biosynthesized gold nanoparticles were successfully used as catalysts in Knoevenegal reactions, and adducts were obtained with high yields under mild conditions. These metallic nanoparticles follow the precepts of Green Chemistry and demonstrate significant potential as efficient catalysts for organic synthesis reactions. coredata.dc:description: Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have found widespread applications across chemistry, physics, biology, and medicine. Microorganisms can be used for the biological synthesis of nanoparticles under controlled conditions. In this study, the endophytic bacterium Priestia megaterium (CBMAI 2841), isolated from Lavandin inflorescences and cultured in a liquid Nutrient Broth medium, was employed for the extracellular biological synthesis of metallic AuNPs (Bio-AuNPs) without the use of toxic solvents. Highlighting the experimental novelty, the utilization of a bacterium sourced from a specific plant origin distinguishes this work from studies employing microorganisms from broader environmental niches or established laboratory strains. The bacterial biomass was separated by centrifugation, and the resulting growth supernatant (20 mL) was reacted with a 1 mmol L−1 aqueous solution of tetrachloroauric(III) acid trihydrate ( ). The bioreduction process was conducted at 32 °C and 130 rpm for 72 h. The formation of Bio-AuNPs was observed as early as 3 h of reaction, a finding confirmed by UV–Vis spectroscopy. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed that the biosynthesized Bio-AuNPs were formed through self-assembly and coalescence of smaller primary nanoparticles, resulting in an average final size of 45 nm. The aqueous suspension of Bio-AuNPs exhibited good colloidal stability, characterized by a zeta potential of approximately −18 mV and a hydrodynamic size of around 70 nm. The Bio-AuNPs were successfully applied as catalysts (0.4 mg solid Bio-AuNPs, 50 °C, 30 min, 5 mL ethanol) in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction using malononitrile and a series of aromatic aldehydes (benzaldehyde, 4-bromobenzaldehyde, 4-ethylbenzaldehyde, 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, 4-fluorobenzaldehyde, 3-nitrobenzaldehyde, 4-nitrobenzaldehyde, 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde, 3-pyridinecarboxaldehyde, furan-2-carbaldehyde, and 2-thiophenecarboxaldehyde). Notably, high yields (70%–99%) of the Knoevenagel adducts were achieved with a low catalyst mass loading within a short reaction time, using a common solvent (ethanol) at a mild temperature, suggesting enhanced catalytic efficiency compared to some reported Bio-AuNP catalysts. The bacterium P. megaterium (CBMAI 2841) demonstrated efficiency in the extracellular biological synthesis of AuNPs. The rapid synthesis combined with promising catalytic activity underscores the potential of this specific bio-inspired approach.
